meanings.def: willing to understand and respect other people’s behaviour, opinions, etc., especially when they are different from your own; believing people should be able to choose how they behave
examples: liberal attitudes/views/opinions
He is relatively liberal on social issues.
His attitudes are fairly liberal.
Her parents are very liberal and allow her a lot of freedom.
His later films reflect the more liberal values of the 1960s.
In some countries there is a more liberal attitude to euthanasia.

meanings.def: wanting or allowing a lot of political and economic freedom and supporting steady social, political or religious change
examples: Some politicians want more liberal trade relations with Europe.
liberal democracy
liberal theories
a liberal politician
a broadly liberal policy programme
a broadly liberal set of policies
comparatively liberal in trade matters

meanings.def: connected with the British Liberal Party in the past, or a Liberal Party in another country

examples: She is very liberal with her money.
I think Sam is too liberal with his criticism (= he criticizes people too much).
Divorced fathers should have liberal access to their children.
We ate cake with liberal amounts of whipped cream.
She's very liberal with her advice!

meanings.def: a liberal education is about increasing somebody’s general knowledge and experience rather than particular skills
examples: a liberal education
a liberal translation of the text
a liberal interpretation of the law

meanings.def: a person who understands and respects other people’s opinions and behaviour, especially when they are different from their own
examples: He liked to think of himself as a liberal.

meanings.def: a person who supports political, social and religious change
examples: Reform is popular with middle-class liberals.

meanings.def: a member of the British Liberal Party in the past, or of a Liberal Party in another country
